text:
...for posterity, it's worth remembering that forest fire smoke started to roll into Edmonton on July 19th. The heatwave continued until the 23rd, but the smoke likely supressed temperatures a bit.
And Calgary's all-time record Low on July 24th was an extremely smoky day.
author: did:plc:p34cowxpwc5etgv33tm2jupm

text:
...while Edmonton was well into the 30s, Calgary spent a bunch of July near 30°C.
Their heatwave wasn't as extreme, but had some notable events:
4 32°C Highs in-a-row (2nd most)
8 30°C Highs in-a-row (tying 1917's record)
10 28°C Highs in-a-row (2nd most)
public.tableau.com/shared/34YWD...
author: did:plc:p34cowxpwc5etgv33tm2jupm

text:
...with a deepfreeze & heatwave, Edmonton's 2024 temperatures spanned 73.9°C, from January 14th's Low of -37.7°C to July 10th's High of 36.2°C.
That's the largest range since 1950.
2021 covered 72°C.
1886 & 1936 both have the record with 80.5°C.
public.tableau.com/shared/DGBJ4...

text: Guessing, based on some of the responses to the photos I take, that people wildly overestimate Icelandic summer temperatures. A sunny 15˚C is a warm summer day. Anything around or over 20˚C is a heatwave and the all-time record for Reykjavík is just over 25˚C 😎

text: Adult body sizes were also sensitive to stressor combinations, heatwave duration and instar timing in nuanced ways. L4 heatwaves probably cancel out high humidity benefits. 100% Parasitoid mortality after 72 hr heatwaves applied early (L4) makes generalising this a bit tricky! 5/

text:
Larval development times increased with heatwave duration under some, but not all stressor combinations & L4 vs L5 timing. Humidity affected H-alone more than Parasitoids. Hard to summarise in 300 chars, so here's the fig. 
The paper's #openaccess, you can find details there! 4/

text:
Just gone into heatwave measures:

Watch indoor-outdoor thermometer. Once morning's hotter outside than in, close doors and windows. 

Once evening's cooler outside than in, open doors and windows. PLUS open loft-hatch, so hot air rises out of loft ventilators, drawing in cooler air from outside.🫠 🫡

Meds that may make you more sensitive to heat include:
~ Anticholinergics
~ Antihistamines
~ Diuretics
~ ADHD stimulant meds
~ SSRIs

text:
I guess I'm not communicating well.

What Im asking is when British people hear the word heatwave do they feel in their GUTS "oh no, a natural disaster!!! Wed better get ready and alter our lives to weather this significant weather event" or does the word not carry any specific negative connotation?

text: They're pretty much the same. The technical definition is what gets the papers declaring a heatwave.

text:
All of this & also if you live in a temperate zone and find yourself in a heatwave:

You need to drink more water than you think you do. A *lot* more.

If it's been >1hr since you needed the toilet, go drink 8-9oz of water.

First signs of a headache, start drinking 20-30oz.

Dehydration is no joke.

text:
Generally avoid heavy meals.

And last, but far from least, hyponatremia is a thing.

Hyponatremia happens when you sweat a lot, replace the lost fluids, but don't replace the lost salt.

During a heatwave, you need to increase your sodium intake. You can do this with sports drinks, salt tablets...

text:
Next result of a marine heatwave in line with their self-amplifying feedback character - location: west European Shelf

A high-pressure system (less clouds/weak winds) and the advection of tropical moist air caused it.

Over the marine heatwave a positive cloud feedback was observed - less clouds
